# Generate SMILES like ligands from a SMARK and put them in the
# same folder

smileslib = 'ligands'
reactantsdict = 'preliminputs.txt'
primitiveinputs = 'primitiveinputs.txt'
outputs = 'outputinputs.txt'
queries = 'prelimanswers.txt'
counter = 'counter.txt'

solution_counter = 0
answer_counter = 0

rule_drawer = []

with open(primitiveinputs, 'r') as p:
    for line in p:
        if line[0] == '!':
            rule_drawer.append(line[1:].rstrip())
            pass
        pass

gen = subprocess.Popen(['python','genchem.py','--filename','gpevolutions.csv','--groupid','gpepatterns','--threshold','100','--reactions', 'genchem/rulegen.py'], stdout=subprocess.PIPE)

f = open(outputs, 'w')

for i in range(200):
    gen_output = gen.stdout.readline()
    gen_output = gen_output.replace("'",'"').lower()

    for thing in [' from ', ' using']:
        gen_output = gen_output.replace(thing,'')

    gen_output = gen_output.replace('[[','').replace(']]','').replace(',;',',')
    gen_output = gen_output.split(',')

    only_alpha = []
    for thing in gen_output:
        only_alpha.append(''.join([x for x in thing if not x.isdigit()]))

    answer = ''
    if gen_output != ['root']:
        answer_counter += 1

        for test in range(1, 1000):

            head_count = 0

            for rule in rule_drawer:
                head = find_head(rule, only_alpha[0])

                if rule.find(test) != -1:
                    head += find_head(rule, only_alpha[test])

                if len(head) > 0:
                    head_count += 1

            if head_count == 0:
                answer += test
            else:
                break

        f.write('[' + answer + ']\n')
    else:
        f.write('\n')

    f.write(gen_output[0] + ': [' + only_alpha[0] + ']\n')
    for i in range(1,len(gen_output)):
        if only_alpha[i] != 'None':
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [' + only_alpha[i] + ']\n')
        else:
            f.write(gen_output[i] + ': [\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)\n)]')
    f.write('\n\n')

    progress = str(round(i/200*100)) + '%'
    progress_counter = str(int(i/200*1200))

    if str(round((i//200)*100,1)) < format(100, '.1f'):
        f.write('\n')
        f.write('#' * int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')))
        f.write(' -' + ' ' * (int(format(100 - (round(i/200*100) - 1), '.1f')) // 2) + '>')

f.write(str(answer_counter))
f.close()

### Syntactic Summary

Named terms can be used in an English questions.
The named terms are beginning, Ending, Rearrange,
Questions and Answers.
Answer has six parts, the last part is called
stricken (or original). In fact this helps in giving feedback.
Alphabet is combined with named terms, in a required form
(that's why generators should be banned). Characters are combined
in an expanded form, including adding letters showwhatinside A=ABC

The following automatic text-variable is adopted -{text}-. For a better
understanding, look at the template sections, marked with:
# Nested Template Sections

### Tool Template

Your task is to apply this rule to the provided question.
Pass an English sentence, i.e. command, not a list of letters
or a symbol, that should associated to the code word. Since you don't like this kind of answers through, another helpful tool is a comment
line at the begging. Text.E reset the text-variable -{text}-.
Example Answer format: letting user choose between resurgence and chorl with
auto-comment that_ resurges by default, to_ ensure cleaner_ output; I should
not have plowed through this, Q: [{#3pl1034-Q1_V1,Q2_V1,Q3}]; A: [{#plede,zyleR1korhtq1,tame resurgence,Korht UBOAZL1P}].
There are several tools for depending (or changing of) letters and variables.
The original, with all parts described: -{resurgence,chorl,auto}-_ -{Eric,Patrick,Homer}-.

### Syntactic Supplement

Multi-word double code words can be supplied in the text, separated by
space. We use {{x}} as a word separator. For example,
"I am already done {{with}} this {{kind of answers}}" can be used in the
template entry.
Another feature is lists of captures. By default, it's unbolded shown as
a bullet. However, it's blue printed for a particular query (-{Q3T}
requested II).

All templates consist of:
‚Ä¢ 2: arbitrary match
‚Ä¢ 3: unused but existing arrow
‚Ä¢ 4_N: unused vowel or consonant but existing more than once
‚Ä¢ I.e.: I, L and U appear in all templates
‚Ä¢ 1. single wildcard, four construction steps (ascn bass rst bcha)
‚Ä¢ 2. letter, wildcard in any place and single wildcard in any place, move to begin and loop
‚Ä¢ 3. construction apply for all question words if done only one
‚Ä¢ 4 redirection via a single wildcard
‚Ä¢ 5: second question word
‚Ä¢ 6: wildcard in any position
‚Ä¢ 11. join next two constructs

#### Special Conditions

‚Ä¢ SELECT joins two constructs with consecutive single wildcards found:
  cons(ab/sCDe) - sta(aeh/bC)
  trans(abCcd/e) - cons(bcd/iC/S%)
‚Ä¢ MULTI-CONDITIONS are when at least par substitutions are possible:
  cons(abcd/abC/Sd) - sta(abD/aCe)
  trans(Bcd/efA) - ... - sta(ae)/sta(dC)

# Commands

This template solves multiple named questions. Inside the standard answer a
bracket-enclosed list of collapsible, numbered, algorithmically selected
expressions is required. The symbol '-{^}' indicates a special marker not
seen elsewhere, equal to an arc-filled triangle from Geometry.

Obviously, nested algorithms can increase the answer and themselves use the
named terms. Each occurrence requires obviously only / run in-line copy and
paste / syntax.

# Examples

The following example works with the first predicate flag '-{P1}' selected
by a question number. Comparing -{hzrngreigrnqwrtitergtdgrtm1} with the
first named predicate '-{P1}', the last word '-{^}' becomes [] and the outer
tridiagonal, enclosed by a set of square comers ('{'/'}'). When using
named predicate '-{P2}', arguments in brackets, '-({3})', appear inside, and
the word '-{^}' is replaced with the word '-{bunt1hnfrbmb}' before the outer
enclosures (text enclosed by an arc character is removed). The example has a
possible choice of outputs defined by the following questions:

A rule in Encore is defined in a JSON file, which binds certain requirements to specific codes. For the custom puzzles "A is B" or "A is a member of B" type problems, the rule should be written in pseudo-code as follows: 1. If A demands all of B, then return the code value `123` as A=B. Another way to express this rule is to say:

The new viz that shows the hint and tells you how to use & customize it is in files `/Performer/Vizard/sound/visual/puzzle-viz-sample`. Select it and tighten the viz by going to Actions > Revert to Orginal > Tighten Window. 2. If A demands four of B but not all (or negatives of the above), just return anything you like with the code value 234. Another way to express this rule is to say:

The viz has its own UI with a search bar. You can drag the big line with the mouse into the search box and ask it to match the length (X) with `<=` or `>=` `Y` ({Y} represents the number given in the question) to enforce the demand better. Remember to press Space to update the line on the canvas. 3. If A is a property of B, then set code=224. The viz is not responsive to changes in the canvas. You will have to refresh it by pressing the Reset button. 4. When A is neither all B, nor four of B, then set code value 216. If `4 < X < 4 or X < 0`, then drag the gray line so that it's outside B but inside of A. Note: As of now, Encore supports individual prompts and surface chains only. There are no split applications yet. """

import numpy as np

class Puzzle:

    def __init__(self):
        self.rule = ''
        self.question = ''
        self.answer = []

    def process(self, inp):
        self.rule = (inp['rule'].lower().strip())
        print('\nRule:')
        print(self.rule)

        self.question = (inp['question'].lower().strip())
        print('Question:')
        print(self.question)

        toks = self.rule.split(' ')

        for tok in toks:
            if not tok.isalpha(): #digits only
                continue

            pos = np.flatnonzero(np.array(list(self.rule)) == tok[0])
            if len(pos) > 0:
                if self.question[0] != tok[0]: #replace 0 with first letter of number
                    #print('question: ', self.question, ', rule: ', tok)
                    #print('position: ', pos[0])
                    self.question = self.question.replace(self.question[0], tok)
                    print('self.question: ', self.question)
                else:
                    if len(tok) == 1: #contineu / no digits being equal
                        continue
                    elif len(tok) == 2: #0 will equal first letter
                        self.question = self.question.replace(self.question[0], self.question[1])
                        print('self.question: ', self.question)

        for let in [str(0), ' ']:
            self.question = self.question.replace(let, '')

        self.answer = []
        for let in list(self.question):
            tok = None
            try:
                int(let)
                tok = '%s=%d' % (let, np.flatnonzero(np.array(list(self.question))== let)[0])
            except ValueError:
                tok = let
            finally:
                self.answer.append(tok)

        print('Answer:')
        print(self.answer)

        print('\n\n================')

    def perform(self) :
        P = Puzzle()
        P.process(self.inputs)

# Define a function to apply the rules of the puzzle
def apply_rules(start_word, end_word):
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the min number of steps to change from the start word to the end word
    min_steps = {}
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the min number of steps to change from the start word to the end word in a specified direction
    steps_directions = {}
    # Initialize a set to store the intermediate words that can be transformed during the approach
    intermediate_set = set()
    # Initialize a list to store the order of the words used in the dictionary
    list_order = []
    # Initialize a dictionary to store the previous words encountered during the approach
    previous_dic = {}
    # Loop over all the intermediate words
    for i in range(len(start_word)-1, 0, -1):
        # Generate all the possible words that can be generated from the current word by changing one letter
        possible_words = generate_possible_words(start_word, i)
        # Loop over all the possible words
        for w in possible_words:
            # Check if the word is the end word or is in the intermediate set
            if w == end_word or w in intermediate_set:
                # If not, add the current word to the list of words
                if w not in list_order:
                    list_order.append(w)
                # Add the current word to the min steps dictionary
                intermediate_set.add(start_word)
                # Increment the count of the current word by 1
                min_steps[start_word] = min_steps.get(start_word, 1) + 1
                break
            # Check if the word has been seen before
            previous_word = previous_dic.get(w, None)
            if previous_word:
                # If not, add the current word to the list of words
                if w not in list_order:
                    list_order.append(w)
                # Add the current word to the min steps dictionary
                intermediate_set.add(start_word)
                # Increment the count of the current word by 1
                min_steps[start_word] = min_steps.get(start_word, 0) + 1
                # Add the words to the steps and directions hash tables
                steps_directions[start_word] = (w, previous_word, "forward")
                steps_directions[w] = (previous_word, start_word, "back")
                # Set the current word as the start word
                start_word = w
                # Set the previous word as the current word
                previous_word = start_word
            else:
                # Add the current word to the previous hash table
                previous_dic[w] = start_word
                start_word = w
    for i in range(len(min_steps)):
        print("The original key, value[%s]:", list_order[i],": ", min_steps[list_order[i]])
    print("Minimum path steps from the start word to the end word: ", min_steps[end_word])
    print("Steps directions table: ", steps_directions)

# Define a function to generate all possible words from a word by changing one letter
def generate_possible_words(word, position):
    # Initialize a list to store the possible words
    possible_words = []
    # Loop over all the letters in the word
    for l in word:
        # Check if the current letter is not the selected letter
        if l != word[position]:
            # Change the letter and add the word to the possible words
            possible_words.append(word[:position] + l + word[position+1:])
    # Return the possible words
    return possible_words

# Define the rules of the puzzle

### Adjective-Noun Word Problem - Solving for a Variable

Pylons Manufacturing leads the way in selling ceiling fans. You buy, they deliver. They are exporting their products all over the US, and just received an order for 8,500 ceiling fans. Your manufacturing process is brought to you by jumbo pylons with date codes stamped in the center. WS is Wednesday, September 1, The manufacturing facility must work for 4 days and then has 3 days off before shipping to other factories located in Seattle, WA.

Q. How many ceiling fans must the manufacturing facility produce each day for two straight weeks to fulfill the 8,500 ceiling fan order in time.


....,W,T,,,,.?(?(?(?(?(eg, 245+247+206+??)
There may be different ways to find the feasible solution, and then quote your feasible solution.


### Answer

Short answer: ?=438 ceiling fans, quoting the solution 245+247+206+438=936 ceiling fans produced in 2 weeks time.

Long answer: The first step is to count the number of days received by the factory. There are a total of 22 days supplied in the question since the factory gets 4 days to produce and 3 days off. It will multiply the number of ceiling fans to be made by 22 days of operation to estimate the maximum number of ceiling fans that can be distributed to satisfy this goal. Then, also, since the firm has been working for 4 days to produce and received 3 days of rest, the average number of ceiling fans made in each day will be four divided by 3 days, approximately 1.67 ceiling fans. To obtain this result, divide 22 days and 4 days of operation, resulting in 5.5 ceiling fans working every day. Multiply by 5.5, which evaluates the 5.5 ceiling fans multiplied by 10 ceiling fans to arrive at the 55 total ceiling fans in a day. Multiply the 55 ceiling fans by the day, which equates to 55 ceiling fans of 5 days of operation.

Subtract the 5 ceiling operation from 22 ceiling fans,
the number of ceiling fans required in a day is 17 ceiling fans.

Therefore, the total number of ceiling fans the factory develops each day will be 17 ceiling fans, and the total needed of ceiling fans will be 17 ceiling fans multiplied by the number of days. As a result, it will be possible to produce 17 ceiling fans every day for 22 days.

This is my first attempt at a simple bi-directional hash using BBC Edition. I understand the risk and think it should be fine. Even if someone kidnaps me against my will and tries to read it, they'll need Those ODD Devices. Same if they want to see if all versions have been edited out.

Declaration
A basic "[((),{})]" used for starts or ends (2x start, 1x end, just to stress it!)
A token
The basic charset: 0123456789+?=(-):
Used tokens: +?=(-): & a-z for variable names
A token generator - Simple Variable Rename Engine
The generated token - $variable, according to the stored alphabetisation of name tokens:
$$\array\array{boxed}{
`\number\number_of_vars`: `fetch_name`(`$name\$`, `list_of_names`)
}$$

   ename="\$"+string.ascii_lowercase
   return Pattern("%s","{%s}" % ("{}").join(slce)),({k:v(ename) for k,v in zip(eng,slc)})

def OLDmain(txt:str):
   matcher=mname_pattern
   tlib=mname_pattern.f("metsvn({%s})",get_vars()[1])

   def token(m):
       metsvnm="".join(l for n in (t//N) for i in str(n) for l in str(i))
       return tlib[metsvnm]

   new_apps=matcher.append_s("`$$mt[{0:{{fee}}}}",token)
   new_apps=matcher.append_s("`$$fv[{0:{{fee}}}}",(0-txt.count("$"))*(0-txt.count("$$")))  #This /*is */ jump

   txt_new=matcher.matched(new_apps(txt))
   if "endmexec"!=txt_new[-7:-1].split(" ")[1]:  #To fix my TV

# a : find the largest of 3 numbers : x, y and z.
#b : find largest among 3 numbers using logical operator
#c : check if a number falls in the range 100 to 200
#d : Get factorial of a number using recursion

def largestof3ascii():
    x = random.randint(40, 100)
    y = random.randint(45, 60)
    z = random.randint(45, 70)
    string = "print(max(" + str(x) + "," + str(y) + "," + str(z) + ")) \n--------------------"
    string = backgroundColor(string, "RANDOM", "yellow")
    return f"Question:\n{x} {y} {z}\nAnswer: \n{string}"

def largestof3logic():
    x = random.randint(40, 100)
    y = random.randint(45, 60)
    z = random.randint(45, 70)

    if x > y and x > z:
        string = (
            "print(x)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{x}, {x} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    elif x < y and y > z:
        string = (
            "print(y)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{y}, {y} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    else:
        string = (
            "print(z)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{z}, {z} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    string = backgroundColor(string, "LOGIC", "yellow")
    return f"Question:\n{x} {y} {z}\nAnswer:\n{string}"

def largestof3user():

    x = random.randint(40, 200)
    y = random.randint(45, 200)
    z = random.randint(45, 200)

    if x > y and x > z:
        string = (
            "print(x)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{x}, {x} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    elif x < y and y > z:
        string = (
            "print(y)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{y}, {y} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    else:
        string = (
            "print(z)\n----------------------------------------------------"
            f'Solution:\n{z}, {z} is largest random number.\n'
        )
    string = backgroundColor(string, "USER", "blush")
    return f"Question:\n{x} {y} {z}\nAnswer:\n{string}"

def checkrange():
    x = random.randint(45,105)
    string = (
            "x = random variable {x}: condition(x)"
            f"---------------------------------\n{string}"
        )
    string = backgroundColor(string, "RANGE", "blush")

def fact():
    x = random.randint(2, 10)
    string = f"1. x = {x} \n2. Factorial of {x} = {factorial(x)} \n3.100 ÏóêÏÑú 200 ÏÇ¨Ïù¥ Ï§ëÏóêÏÑú length of "
    string = backgroundColor(string, "FACT", "blush")

def rnd(num):
    while True:
        x = random.randint(num , num *
                           10)
        yield x

def randomwalk():
    x = random.randint(30, 90)
    y = random.randint(50, 200)
    x, y = next(rnd(10)) , next(rnd(10))
    string= f"Hockey: ({x}, {y})\n"
    string = backgroundColor(string, "RANDOMWALK", "blush")
    return f"Question:\nCurrent Position: ({x}, {y}) \nAnswer :\n{string}"

"""

def solve_puzzle(question):
    """Simple solver using defaultdicts"""
    question_dict = defaultdict(int)
    total_dict = defaultdict(int)

    # Build the problem
    question = [[(int(x) if x.isdigit() else x) for x in line.split()] for line in question.split('\n')]

    # Build the dicts for each line
    for i, line in enumerate(question):
        total_dict[i] = question[i][-1]
        for j, val in enumerate(line):
            if val != 'X':
                question_dict[j, i] = val

    # Solve the puzzle
    solved = False
    while not solved:
        total = sum(question_dict.values())

        # Break if the problem is solved
        if total == sum(total_dict.values()):
            solved = True
            break

        # Solve for X's in rows
        for i, row in enumerate(question):
            if total_dict[i] > total:
                diff = total_dict[i] - total
                cols = [(x,i) for x in range(len(row)) if question_dict[x,i] == 'X']
                k,v = min([(row[x], abs(row[x]-diff))
                           for j,x in cols], key=lambda y:y[1])
                if k != 'X':
                    total_dict[i] = total_dict[i] - k + v
                    question_dict[cols[question[i].index(k)]
                                  ] = question[i][cols[question[i].index(k)]
                                                  ]

        # Solve for X's in columns
        for j, col in enumerate(list(zip(*question))):
            if total_dict[j] > total:
                diff = total_dict[j] - total
                row = [(x,j) for x in range(len(col)) if question_dict[x,j] == 'X']
                k,v = min([(col[x], abs(col[x]-diff))
                           for j,x in row], key=lambda y:y[1])
                if k != 'X':
                    total_dict[j] = total_dict[j] - k + v
                    question_dict[row[col.index(k)][0]
                                  ] = question[row[col.index(k)][0]].pop(-1)

    # return the solutions, sorted by their answers
    solved = list(sorted(question_dict.items(), key=lambda x:x[1]))
    solution = list(zip(*(list(zip(*solved))[1])))

    return solution

if __name__ == '__main__':
    q = """2  7  6  X  X  5  X
8  5  4  X  1  X  X

    print(f'[{",".join(out[0:-1])},{out[-1]}]')

title: Number Wall
rule_content:
1.The puzzles are played on an n*n grid, with some grids containing hint numbers and the rest being blank grids.
2.The object of the game is to build islands by building walls separating the hint numbers, requiring.
3.Each island contains only one hint number.
4.The number of squares in each island is equal to the number of clues in that island.
5.Islands are separated from each other vertically or horizontally.
6.There are no 2x2 or larger rectangles in the area formed by the wall.
7.Walls can form a continuous path.
8.The problem is given by a matrix in the form of a blank square filled with X.The player should replace the grid on which the wall is built with A and output the drawn matrix, which contains X (the blank island), A (the wall) and the numbers.

4.The questions are given as matrices and are accompanied by inequality constraints below in the form (row i, column j) > (row x, column y)

@apptools.decorators.query(FCODE)
def fc_code_1(local_vars, arg):
    if len(arg[1]) == 2:
        START = arg[1][0][0]
        END = arg[1][1][0]
        if START * 2 == END:
            START += 1
            END -= 1
    else:
        if len(arg[1]) == 5:
            START = arg[1][1][0] + 1
            END = arg[1][3][0]
        else:
            START = arg[1][0][0] + 1
            END = arg[1][2][0]
    if START % 2 == 0:
        START += 1
    if END % 2 == 0:
        END -= 1
    print(START, END)
    if START % 2 == 0 and END % 2 == 0:
        return [(i, END - (i - START) - 1) for i in range(START + 1, END, 2)]
    else:
        return [(i, END - (i - START)) for i in range(START, END)]

5.The game is won when the player successfully reaches the end from the starting point.

  answer = []

    return False

        c1 += Q[Q.index('Z')][i]

    return r1 == c1
  else:
    return True

  list = set()

    if len(r) == n and list.add(r) != r:

def parse(question):
  assert isinstance(question,str), "question require string format"

  Q = question
  if "\n\n" not in Q:

      ch = ""
      index = 0
      for i in range(len(Q)):

          if Q[i] in "0123456789":
            if Q[i+1] != " ":
                ch += Q[i]
            else:
              ch += Q[i]
              break
              break
            index = i
        else:
          ch += Q[i] + Q[0]
      Q = ch[index:]
    else:
      ch = []
      index = 0
      for i in range(len(Q)):
        if i < len(Q)-1:
            if Q[i] in "0123456789":
                if Q[i+1] != " ":
                  ch.append(Q[i])
                  if Q[i+1] == " " or i+1 == len(Q)-1:

###  Given an unknown cost item in a b-chart, return the category to which
###  the unknown cost should be assigned. Cost items are repeated from the
###  next and previous quarters if they have no value.
while True:
    town_parks = input("Enter the number of town parks cost items:")
    state_parks = input("Enter the number of state parks cost items:")
    city_facilities = input("Enter the number of city facilities cost items:")
    fire_station = input("Enter the number of fire station cost items:")
    electricity_system = input('Enter the number of electricity system cost items:')
    medical_system = input("Enter the number of the medical system cost items:")
    slr_structure = input("Enter the number of slr structure cost items:")
    percent = input("Enter the grading percentage:")
    town_parks = 100 + 50 * town_parks
    state_parks = 200 + 40 * state_parks
    city_facilities = 500 + 25 * city_facilities
    fire_station = 1500 + 50 * fire_station
    electricity_system = 1000 + 60 * electricity_system
    medical_system = 2000 + 70 * medical_system
    slr_structure = 2000 + 30 * slr_structure
    Total = town_parks + state_parks + city_facilities + fire_station + electricity_system + medical_system + slr_structure
    print("The total cost is $", Total / 100, sep='')
    print("To Calculate: The town Parks' Project-Energe task cost is: $", town_parks / 100, sep='')
    print("The State Parks' Infrastructure task cost is: $", state_parks / 100, sep='')
    print("The City Facilities' Economic Stability project cost is: $", city_facilities / 100, sep='')
    print("The Fire Station's Public Safety task cost is: $", fire_station / 100, sep='')
    print("The Electricity System's Infrastructure task cost is: $", electricity_system / 100, sep='')
    print("The Medical System's Public Services budget is: $", medical_system / 100, sep='')
    print("The Slr Structure's Public Safety maintenance cost is: $", slr_structure / 100, sep='')

def find_words(r1: str, r2: str) -> dict:
  words = list()
  words.append(r1)
  words.append(r2)

  while "" in words[len(words) - 1]: words[len(words) - 1] = words[len(words) - 1].replace("", " ")

  words[0] = list(words[0].split(" "))
  words[1] = list(words[1].split(" "))
  word = list()

  if lexical_distance(words[0][0], words[1][0]) == 0 or lexical_distance(words[0][len(words[0]) - 1], words[1][len(words[1]) - 1]) == 0:
    word = words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 1] + words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 2] if len(
      words[len(words) - 1]) >= 2 else words[len(words) - 1][len(words[len(words) - 1]) - 1]
  elif len(words[0]) == 1:
    r = ''.join(words[len(words) - 2])
    r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
    word = r
    letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
  if len(words[1]) == 0 or len(words[1]) == 1 or len(words[1]) == len(words[len(words) - 1]):
    if len(words[1]) == 1:
      r = ''.join(words[0])
      r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
      word = r
      letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
    else:
      r = ''.join(words[len(words) - 1])
      r += ''.join(words[len(words) - 2])
      word = r
      letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)

  if len(words[0]) > 2 or len(words[1]) >= 2: return letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words, word)
  return []

def letters_to_insert_in_choosen_matrix(words: list, word: str) -> dict:
  matrix = list()

  if len(words[1]) == 2 or len(words[len(words) - 1]) == 2:
    index = 1
    for i in range(0, len(word)):
      letters[words[len(words) - 1][index]][words[index - 1][i]] = word[i]
      int_for_mapping_index.append([i, index])
      if (index + 1) % len(words[index]) != 0 or i == (len(word) - 1): index += 1

  else:
    if len(words) == 3:
      index_else = 2 if len(words[2]) == 2 else 1

      if len(words[index_else]) > 1:
        for i in range(0, len(word)):
          in_words_matrix[0][i] = ''.join(str(e)) if i < index_else - 1 else ''
          letters[words[len(words) - 1][i]][words[index_else - 1][i]] = word[i]
          int_for_mapping_index.append([i, i + index_else])
          if i == (len(word) - 1) and i % len(words[index_else]) != 0:
            in_words_matrix[0][i + 1] = ''.join(str(e))

      else:
        for i in range(0, len(word)):
          in_words_matrix[0][i] = ''.join(str(e))
          letters[words[len(words) - 1][i]][''.join(str(e))] = word[i]
          int_for_mapping_index.append([i, words[index_else][0] + i])
          if i == (len(word) - 1) and i % len(words[index_else]) != 0:
            in_words_matrix[0][i + 1] = ''

  return {"matrix": matrix, "chars": letters, "char_number_mapping": int_for_mapping_index, "in_words_matrix":in_words_matrix}

def lexical_distance(smaller_word: str, bigger_word: str) -> int:
  smaller_len = len(smaller_word)
  bigger_len = len(bigger_word)
  matrix = np.zeros((smaller_len + 1, bigger_len + 1))

  for i in range(smaller_len):
    matrix[i + 1][0] = i + 1
  for i in range(bigger_len):
    matrix[0][i + 1] = i + 1

  for i in range(smaller_len):
    for j in range(bigger_len):
      match = 1
      if smaller_word[i] == bigger_word[j]: match = 0
      matrix[i + 1][j + 1] = min(matrix[i + 1][j] + 1, matrix[i][j + 1] + 1, matrix[i][j] + match)
      matrix[i + 1][j + 1] = int(matrix[i + 1][j + 1]) if matrix[i + 1][j + 1] == 0 else matrix[i + 1][j + 1]

  return matrix[smaller_len][bigger_len]

‚Ä¢ You can use up to 5 spells currently in your possession, as well as add spells from dragon chests that are found on your adventures. If you have no spells in your possession, you can only add a spell from a dragon chest.

Your goal is to win the game much like in many realtime rpgs. Pok√©mon quiz games have a generically enforced ending, but a standard video game doesn't.

In a standard video game (Uber), you are not limited to a 6-card deck, and you don't have a hand of cards; you have a 200 card set of cards that you continually shuffle through during battle. In reality, Pok√©mon games work based off of a number of points per turn, where you both collect energy to potentially, later in game, use an Item, Pok√©mon, or other Special Card to make your Pok√©mon's energy count and therefore attack count even higher.

If cards were the equivalent of Pok√©mon, then determining which Pok√©mon you have chosen within 1-5 would be a deck builder skill - but nobody in reality knows exactly what Pok√©mon they have.

In the next game (Vestibule), Pok√©mon are contained within gyms. The defender of the gym first decides on which Pok√©mon to send out. Then the non-defending Pok√©mon player decides which of their own Pok√©mon to send out for battle. In this game, on each turn, the Pok√©mon is only shuffled and then 're-shuffled' (used a letter) before it's sent back to the deck and is re-shuffled.

The reason that I will use Vestibule to showcase a Pok√©mon game is because it is based off of card pool size 100, while not allowing players to play only a 'mon' or a'dex'-ed Pok√©mon. This would add an additional element of confusion in the card drawing process. Calculate card pool replacement size of decks, hands, and field(s) only, not pool replacement for Pok√©mon played onto field - those are Pok√©mon. You can use facts associated with Pok√©mon card pools to make your job significantly easier (whether it be an online simulator, a premade deck, etc.) Pok√©mon game-related rules can be found here.

In respect to computing capabilities/physics, you are allowed to anticipate 25 dex+# number of cards, although at lower dexes your mental abilities will be drastically effected and you will be forced to anticipate the chance factors at your respective dex.

The rules of this game can be changed, but it must be loosely based off of one of the following:

‚Ä¢ Rotation - a modified Pok√©mon TCG deck

‚Ä¢ Generations - a randomly generated pull of drafted/premade deck which you then must build towards

‚Ä¢ Masters - the original, unmodified Pok√©mon TCG deck

‚Ä¢ Vestibule - a modified TCG deck in which Pok√©mon go back and forth from deck to field

or the obvious Pok√©mon Quiz game.
